segments.text: Imagine a bunch of AI bots arguing
whether a stock should go up or down.
Basically like a hedge fund, but ran by
AI. We're starting to see more of this.
You'd think that it's just a joke, but
the crazy part is it somewhat behaves
like a real team. And today I'm going to
look at something called Trading Agents,
an open- source Python project that's
gaining a lot of attention cuz it
simulates a trading firm but using AI.
Quick warning, this is not financial
advice. It's just a sandbox for
developers who want to experiment with
AI workflows. We have videos coming out
all the time. Be sure to subscribe.
What's interesting here is trading
agents isn't one smartbot. It's a whole
lineup cuz each agent has a job and they
don't always agree. You've got things
like a fundamentals analyst that goes
through company financials, a sentiment
expert to scan social media, news
watchers, a technical analyst that looks
at charts, and then you got two agents
whose job is to argue between bullish
and bearish. This spins up a team of
specialized AI agents using your choice
of model like GPT4 or another one. Now,
under it all, it's built on Langraph for
multi- aent flow. And then it pulls data
from places like Yahoo Finance and Alpa
Vantage. It's super modular and it's
geared for stocks, but yes, I think you
could sneak crypto into it, just not
ETFs. And again, guys, this is
simulation only, but you could play this
out on a demo account, track your moves,
and see how it performs. Now, let me do
a quick demo. You'd expect something
like this to take forever to set up, but
it was actually really fast. The setup
was straightforward and I got it going
in no time. First, I cloned the repo
from their GitHub page. Then, I made a
environment with Python 3. I installed
the requirements file and then I added
my OpenAI and Alpha Vantage API keys. I
was done in like under 2 minutes. You
don't need OpenAI cuz you could also use
Anthropic, Google, or other ones as
well. Now, I really did like the CLI
mode here cuz it was simple. It was just
fun to play with. First, you run the
main script in your terminal. I was
looking at a stock that performed well
in 2025, so I chose Hilton with HLT. I
dropped in a date and then you can
choose which type of analyst you want.
Things like market, social media, news,
fundamentals, but I'm just going to opt
in for all of them for deeper research.
You can then choose how deep you want
the research to go and then choose your
LLM and which two models you want to run
it on. And this is where it gets fun cuz
instead of one model dumping an answer,
the agents start working together like
an actual team, which is pretty cool to
see. Behind the scenes, you're going to
see things like fundamentals crunch
earnings, the sediment pools news and
social media, and then the technical
analyst runs all that technical stuff
like RSI, MACD. Then this debate kicks
off. So bullish argues the upside,
bearish calls out the risk. And at the
end, you're going to get trade
recommendations like buy or sell, plus
the reasoning behind it. So right here
you can see the final conclusion they
all came to based on the data they
found. Now all this ran in the CLI but
if you want to make changes you can
directly affect the Python scripts. Jump
into the main PI file and comes with
everything you need as it's already a
template. You're going to tweak the
default config maybe swap for a deeper
model if you want that and you can set
the number of debate rounds as this will
give you a deeper analysis but it's
going to call that API a lot more so
it's going to be more expensive. Then
you can run it on a ticker and a date.
You don't need to use the CLI. Then you
can just use the script and it will
execute set stock on its own. Now this
is the part that people don't expect.
You might run the same exact thing
twice. You're going to get different
results. It might not always be the
same, but if I rerun it, you might get a
twist because it's non-deterministic.
Also, API calls cost money. Open AAI
tokens, they add up. This is no
different. There are definitely more
cons than pros here because this isn't
something I'd bet money on. But let's
just start with the good. This project
is a win if you're building or learning
multi- aent systems. It's insanely
modular for playing with AI agents.
That's cool. It teaches collaborative AI
systems, which if you're working with
that, also nice. It's open source, which
means you can scale it. And it's perfect
for risk-free back testing. Don't bet
money on it. Now, on the other side,
because there is one, the cons are
there. It chews through APIs like crazy.
It's going to rack up your tokens. You
can see how many times I've ran mine.
Results aren't consistent every time.
You're limited by external data and rate
limits, and it's more stock tuned than
ETFs and everything else out there. So,
it's not hardened for any type of real
world production yet, but I think we can
kind of see where things could be going.
Now, the big picture here, this kind of
system could end up inside everyday
tools for quant devs or even apps like
Robin Hood one day. So, if you're a
developer, here's what might matter to
you. We know agent frameworks are
blowing up. So, if you learn how to
build and control systems like this now,
you're still early. Experiment, break
it, rewire it, play with it. It's open
source. But always do your own digging.
So, yeah, Trading Agents is fun to play
around with if you're into AI, but
nothing here is going to mean you should
use it as financial advice. Have some
fun with it and we'll see you in another
